text: Judith Lynne "Judee" Sill (October 7, 1944 â€“ November 23, 1979) was an American folk rock singer-songwriter and musician. Her songs were inspired by Bach and Christian themes such as the rapture. ==Career== Sill released her debut album in 1971. She later released Heart Food in 1973. When she was alive, she did not find commercial success. When she died, no obituary was published. However after her death, several musicians said that Sill was an inspiration for them. These musicians include Andy Partridge, Liz Phair, Warren Zevon, Shawn Colvin, Steven Wilson, Robin Pecknold, Daniel Rossen, and Bill Callahan. Sill was openly bisexual. Her romance with the singer- songwriter JD Souther inspired her song "Jesus Was a Cross Maker". ==Death== Sill had a drug addiction through much of her life. She died of a drug overdose in Los Angeles, California on November 23, 1979 at the age of 35. ==References== ==Other websites== *Judee Sill Biography *Observer article *Washington Post article by Tim Page *UNCUT article on Sill *Unreleased recordings *"Judee Sill's Posthumous 'Dreams'" *Judee's Epitaph Category:1944 births Category:1979 deaths Category:Drug-related deaths in the United States Category:American folk singers Category:American folk musicians Category:American country guitarists Category:American country singers Category:American pop singers Category:American composers Category:American keyboardists Category:Musicians from Los Angeles Category:Singers from Los Angeles Category:LGBT singers Category:LGBT musicians Category:Bisexual people Category:LGBT people from Los Angeles Category:Singers from Oakland, California Category:Musicians from Oakland, California
title: Judee Sill
